head.title: At Mideast Summit, The Mood Improves

hedline.hl1: At Mideast Summit, The Mood Improves

block.p: At Camp David, the Israeli peace delegation's mood grew more hopeful, and officials outside the negotiations said Prime Minister Ehud Barak believed the chances for success have improved.
President Clinton also sounded upbeat, and rearranged his trip to Japan to return earlier tomorrow and resume his mediation.
At Camp David, the Israeli peace delegation's mood grew more hopeful, and officials outside the negotiations said Prime Minister Ehud Barak believed the chances for success have improved.
President Clinton also sounded upbeat, and rearranged his trip to Japan to return earlier tomorrow and resume his mediation.
Palestinians expressed skepticism, though. One leader, Abu Mazen, offered a rather depressed account of the differences that remain.
Israeli officials said the two sides were entertaining an American proposal for a limited sharing of sovereignty in East Jerusalem. That proposal caused heated commentary in the Middle East.
